newsitem.title: UK: Euro oil swaps flat except "catch-up" light ends.
newsitem.headline: Euro oil swaps flat except "catch-up" light ends.

text.p: European oil swaps were flat on Monday apart from stronger gasoline and naphtha.
Traders said the thin volume was related to public holidays in much of Europe.
Gasoline and naphtha were $2-4 a tonne firmer on the back of attempts to catch up with crude's late Friday gains.
June naphtha was heard done at $191 a tonne while gasoline paper was concluded at $208.50. Physical barges traded at $208 and $209.25 and the market was pegged around $209-210 around 1200 GMT.
Although naphtha firmed on Monday its longer-term prospects were less bullish with several dealers anticipating a tranquil market in June.

Brent CFDs were flat with no deals heard. Traders said it was a normal slow Monday compounded by public holidays. This week was around 20 cents under June, with next week about one cent weaker at 19 cents under.
Gas oil crack spreads were pegged around $4.85-90 a barrel for Q4, only marginally stronger than Friday, while Q1 98 remained backwardated around a flat $4.75.
Heavy fuel swaps were little changed on prompt periods but brokers said the third quarter edged up about $1 a tonne.
June barges were pegged around $86.50 a tonne with July $87.50 and the third quarter at $88.50.
Low sulphur remains about $10 a tonne above barges on the prompt end of the market, slipping to about $7 by the end of the year.
Dealers said the strength on prompt reflected demand from the United States which helped lift quotations about $5 a tonne last Friday.
But that firmness was offset by sluggish demand for Rotterdam barges and growing exports of Russian fuel from St Petersburg.
